The Evolution of Prance under the Third Re- 
public. By Babon PiERitx Db Coubertier. 
Not only a brilliant apology for the Third Re- 
public, but something more‚Äî a remarkably fair 
examination into the ideas and habits which 
form the ba^is of the domestic, civil, and national 
life of France to-day. The chapters on the 
Republic and the Church, Education, Ideas and 
Habits, and the Social Question are the best in 
the volume. The author^s treatment of these 
subjects is as acute as it is comprehensive. It 
has been Jiwtly observed that ideas emanate 
from England, out are worked out to practical 
results in France. As a means of study of theae 
problems this volume will be welcome to all 
students of history or sociology. (New York,

GENERAL. 
Christian MisHoris and Social Progress, A 
Sociological Study of Foreign Missions. By 
the Ret. James S. Dennis, D.D. Vol. I. 
There has been no such comprehensive treat- 
ment of the subject before this. We have, of 
late, been hearing much as to the value of Chris- 
tian missions. Here is the reply‚Äî a reply not 
based on doctrinal, but on purely humanitarian 
questions. The home life, the social relation- 
Hbips, the national spirit‚Äî in one word, the whole 
environment of nonChritstian people is studied. 
The result has been temperately stated by the 
author as a *' present day supplement to the 
cnmulaiive argument of history in defence of 
Chrintianity as a supreme force in the social 
n'peneratioii and elevation of the human race.*' 
It is a matter of regret, however, that in the cir- 
cular for information sent out to the different 
missionaries neither those of the Eastern or 
Roman Churches were included. A work 1 ike this 
cannot afford to be one-sided in its presentation 
of achieved results. (New York, Fleming H. 
RevellCo. $2.50.) 

The Coming People. By Cuarleb F. Dole. 

Pessimism has, we hope, had Its day, and will 
shortly be out of fashion. Certainly this charm- 
ing volume of essays is a harbinger of bet- 
ter days. It is refreshing to have a prophet 

19 



once again lifting np his voice in favor of the 
ideal, and telling as that no permanent practical 
benefit can l>e wrought without a deep belief in 
an ideal. The habitual belief in the evil of the 
world makes the world evil. To alter the world 
we must believe in the triamph of goodness. 
All the depressing probleir 8 confronting our 
civilization in our country in these latter days 
are dealt with‚Äî snch as the Law of Cost, the 
Problem of the Prosperous, the Ideal Democ- 
racy, and the PossibleRevolution. We commend 
the book heartily to *' the coming people," who 
are to prove the fallacy of the pessimism of this 
age. (New York, Thomas Y. Crowell & Co. $1.25.) 

The Bible and Islam ; or. The Injluence of the 
Old and New Testaments on the Religion qf 
Mohammed. By Hknrt Prbbebved Smith, 
D.D. 

An able presentation of a timelv subject. Dr. 
Smith's main argument, and we think ne proves 
it with convincing clearness, is that it was not 
mere Judaism on which Mohammed engrafted 
his scheme of religion, but that rather his sys- 
tem was a Judaistic Christianity adapted to 
Arab conditions. Being imperfectly taught the 
full verities of the Gospel, he grasped but half 
truths. This accoonts both for what is most 
noble and tme in Islamism and for what is 
hard and false. (New York, Charles Scribner's 
Sons. $1.50.) 

Twentu-six Tears qf Missionary Work in China. 

By Grace Stott. Second edition. 

A fascinatinff account of missionary work in 
China by memoers of the Protestant China In- 
land Mission. However much we may differ 
doctrinally from the writer, yet no one can fail 
to be impressed with her patient, loving faith, 
and be gratified at the reward that, after many 
years of unselfish work, came in the conversion 
of snch numbers to Christianity. Mrs. Stott 
quietly says : '* For nearly ten years we saw but 
little spiritual fruit; two or three professed to be- 
lieve in Jesus, but there was no corresponding 
power or change In their lives.'' To work for ten 
years without winning a convert is a rebuke to 
our own faithlessness here at home, when, as 
we say, our work does not prosper. Such lessons 
of patient well-doing, strong faith, and gentle 
ministering as are revealed in these Interesting 
papers can convey teaching to all, even If we do 
not worship the Father in the same way. (New 
York, Fleming H. Revell Co. $1.75.) 

Words for the Church. By the Rev. Edgar 

Gardner Murpht. 

Six able tracts written for popular ase In a 
clear and incisive style. The points dealt with 
are: The Churchman's Controversy Stated; Was 
Henry VIII. the Founder of the Church of Eng- 
land ? Is the Episcopal Church Catholic or Prot- 
estant ? The church at the Beginning ; The 
Church In the Ages ; The Church Doctrine. 
We must, however, protest against the writer's 
assertion that the Apostolic succesflon is not de 
Jlde in the Church. The term may be new, but 
the fact has ever been the Church's doctrine. 
(New York, James Pott & Co. 60 ccnU.) 
" A Way that Seemeth Right. ''An Examination 

of'' Christian Science.'^ ByH.MARTTwHART, 

Dean Hart has here exposed both the weak- 
ness and the strength of '* Christian science.'* 



290 BRIEF NOTES OK CHURCH LITERATURE OF THE YEAR. [1898. 



He has shown the lessons for good and those for 
evil which are to be deduced from a consideration 
of its workings‚Äî its evil, that it attempts to set 
Dp a new Gospel and to make a shipwreck of the 
whole Christian faith, and that it professes to 
be able to cure all manner of ailments ; the 
good, that it can bring rest and peace to manj, 
and that it can heal such ailments as are brought 
on by the deranged condition of the nerves. In 
other words, that its lessons of quietness, medi- 
tation, and self-culture bringtheir own reward. 
His conclusion is twofold : He would have the 
medical profession add to its curriculum some 
such treatment as '* Christian science '* employs; 
and, on the other hand, he would have professors 
of '* Christian science ^* consult the ordinary 
medical practitioner as to the nature of the ail- 
ment they are called upon to cure, so as to de- 
cide whether it comes under the category of a 
nervous disease or not. (New York, James 
Pott & Co. 75 cents.) 

Christianity and Idealism. By John Watson, 

LL.D. 

The first part of this work deals with the 
Christian ideal of life In relation to the Greek 
and Jewish ideals, the second with modem ideal- 
ism in its relation to the Christian ideal of life. 
The work is an attempt to harmonize the ‚Ç¨^erman 
and French systems of philosophy and to a large 
extent modernize their presentation. (New 
York, The Macmillan Co. $1.75.) 

Practical Idealism. By William Db Witt 

Htdk. 

*' Practical idealism,'* the author claims, *4s 
simply a presentation of the familiar facts of 
every-day life in their rational relations, as ele- 
ments in a logical process and parts of an organic 
whole.** He divides his theme into eight parts ; 
four relate to the natural worlds of sense percep- 
tion, aspociation, 'science, and art, and four to 
the spiritual worlds of persons, institutions, 
morality, and religion. (New York, The Mac- 
mlllau Co. $1.50.) 

Christian Ethics. By Thomas B. Strong. 

Under this title we have the Bampton Lectures 
for 1895. The position raainmined in these 
lectures is that the Christian theory of moral 
life is not merely a new formulation of the old 
experience, nor is it merely a restatement of the 
old truths with certain new virtues added, but it 
is a view of life based upon a radically different 
experience of facts. The Christian ethic is the 
detailed presentation of the reconciliation of the 
finite and infinite by the Incarnation in relation 
to the end of life and human nature, the theory 
of virtue, the idea of evil, and the general order 
of the universe as a whole. (New York, Long- 
mans, Green & Co. $5.00.) 

The Social Teachings of Jesus. An Essay on 
Christian Sociology. By Shailer Matthews. 

The purport of this essay appears to be to 
view the teaching of our Lord in relation to 
modem scientific sociology. It purports to bring 
out in its proper rclationHhip the lessons of the 
Goj^pel as they effect the solidarity of the human 
race. A very able prenentaiion of the subject. 
(New York, The Macmillan Co. $1.50.) 



An Introduction to the Study of Socisty. By 
Albion W. Small, Head Professor of Sociol- 
ogy in the University of Chicago, and Gbobob 
E. Vincent, Vice Chancellor of the Chautau- 
qua System of Education. 
The interest evidenced of late years in the in- 
vestigation of social problems has made such a 
work a necessity, if these problems are to be 
studied in a scientific and consecutive manner. 
As a text-book on the subject this work will 
receive wide attention, and will largely help to 
concentrate and systematize thonght on settled 
lines, and thus sociology may pass out of the 
stage of discussion and enter the realm of prac- 
tical politics. As such a manual we heartily 
commend this work. (New York, American 
Book Co. $1.80.) 

ParaMesfor ScJiool and Home. By Wbndbll 

P. Garrison. 

"Lessons in Applied Morals" is what Uie 
author terms these parables. The title of some 
of the subjects will illustrate the anthor*s 
method : Emerson, or the Tenderness for Living 
Things ; Rousseau, or Property ; the Matter- 
horn, or Attainment ; the Brooklyn Bridge, or 
the Insatiable Mind ; the Pyramids, or Heredity. 
(New York, Longmans, Green & Co.) 

Outlines of a Philosophy of Religion. Based on 
Psychology and mstory. By Auoustb Saba- 

TIER. 

The threefold purpose of this work is to deal 
with Religion and its Origin, Christianity and its 
Essence, Dogma and its Nature. Under the first 
head the author treats of the Psychological Ori- 
^n and the Nature of Religion, Rel^on and 
Revelation, Miracle and Inspiration, and the 
Religious Development of Humanity, and thus 
prepares the way for the introduction aud devel- 
opment of Christianity. The Christian principle 
is traced from the direct teaching of our Lord, 
through Jewish, or Messianic Christianity, Cath- 
olic Christianity, and Protestant Christianity. 
The evolution of dogma is a natural conse- 
quence. This the writer treats of from two 
points of view, the historical and the scientific. 
Professor Sabatler is already well and favorablv 
known through his life of S. Paul, and this work 
will enhance the author's reputation as a critical 
student of German or Kantian philosophy. It is 
the logical French mind endeavoring to harmon- 
ize and to reduce into an orderly system mnch 
of the modem philosophy, so as to reconcile it 
with the verities of the C^spel. (New York, 
James Pott & Co. $2.00.) 

Bases qt Religious Belief, Historic and Ideal. 
By Charles Mellen Tyler, D.D., Profewor 
of the Histx)ry and Philosophy of Religion and 
of Christian Ethics, Cornell University. 
In this outline of religions study Dr. Tyler en- 
deavors to bring to a closer agreement theology 
and anthropology, and we have in this work an- 
other attempt to summarisse the conclusions of 
modem thought on man's present being and his 
future. (New York, G.P.Putnam's Sons. $2.00.) 

Social and Ethical Interpretations in MerUal 
Devdopment. By James Mark Baldwin, 
Professor in Princeton University. 
An able study in social psychology, which won 

a well-merited reward by) being crowned with

the gold medal of the Royal Academy of I>eD- 
mark. It is comprehensive in its treatment, 
and exhibits much original thought, especially 
in the chapter on mental development. (New 
York, The MacmUlan Co. S2.¬´0.) 

TTie Growing Revelation. By Amort H. Brad- 

roBD. 

Clever sermons of a devout mind, who, in- 
stead of baling his religion on the Creeds, 
works ont a religion for nimself. working to- 
wards the dogmas of the Creeds rather than 
from them. Tne result is interesting, and shows 
how much the Congregational Chnrch feels the 
net-d of some settled foundation whereon to 
build itp scheme of religion. (New York, The 
MacmillanCo. $1.60.) 

On Human Nature, Etsays (partly poHhumovs) 
in Ethics and Politics. By Arthur Schopbn- 
HAUBR. Selected and translated by T. Bailet 
Saunders. 

Schopenhauer's essays, which are here trans- 
lated, are those on human nature, government, 
free will and fatalism, character, moral instinct, 
and ethical reflections. (New York, The Mac- 
mUlan Co. 90 cents.) 

The Care of Souls. By John Watson, D.D. 

(Ian Maclaren). 

Under this title we have the Lyman Beecher 
Lectures for 1896, which \%'HI amply pay penisal 
by clergy and laity. Beautifully wrhten, they 
contain many most apt Ku^geptione. The topics

A Voice in (he Wilderness. By Algernon Sid- 
net Crafset. 

Under this title Mr. Crapscy pleads for "A 
Restoration of Primitive Chriptlanlty." By that 
term we believe he means a return lo that deep 
sense of personal consecration which so mas- 
tered and overshadowed the early Christians : 
and as one of the means to this end he would 
have smaller dioceses than we have now, so as 
to secure a more complete oversight, or, as he 
himself pute it, "‚Ä¢ We need the mnall diocese in 
order that ice may hare the qi^at Bishop.^'' Mr. 
Crapsey rightiv complains that the priest is the 
only one who has no pnstor ; the bishop has no 
time to give to indlvidnal ministrations. But 
whether a bishop would be h greater bishop or a 
more loving pastor if he had only thirty *>r fifty 
clergy under him is a mooted que¬´?tlon. Still Mr. 
Crai>!¬ªey'8 earnest plea dei¬´erves careful consid- 
eration and especially by our laymen, for what 
the people want God gives them. (New York, 
James Pott & Co. $1, cloth ; 60 cente, paper.) 

The Book of Common Prayer qf the Presbyterian 
Church. Edited by Charles W. Shields, 
D.D. 

We have no space to enter into a detailed 
examination of this work ; we can only say that 
it appears to us to come the nearest to our Prayer 
Book of any publication that we have yet seen. 
(New York, Charles Scribner's Sons. $1.50 net.) 



A Book qf Offices and Prayers for Priest and 
People. Compiled by two Pret'byters of the 
Church. 

A handv mannal for use in parochial ministra- 
tions. The choice of prayers appears a happy 
one, and the spirit of them is thoroughly loyal 
to the American Chnrch. (New York, James 
Pott & Co. $1.00.) 

TheBibUandthe Child. 

Eight rather sketchy essays on the subject of 
how to present the Bible to the young in the 
light of the higher criticism. The spirit of 
these essays is aptly condemned by the anecdote 
given by one of the essayists, Dr. Gladden : *' A 
nttle maid of seven, after listening with interest 
to the reading of Bible stories paraphrased for 
children, said, Mith a sigh, 'Yes, that is good, 
but I like the real Bible better.* " (New York, 
The MacmUlan Co. $1.00.) 

The Devotions qf Bisfiop A ndrewes. Tran slated 
from the Greek and arranged anew by John 
Henrt Newman. 

To this beantifnl edition of an old favorite 
Dr. Morgan Dix has contributed an introduction 
in which he savs: *' Tired and sick of modem 
invention, ana weary of the nnreality of for- 
eign types of devotional literature, we come 
back, with infinite comfort, to the sincere and 
pure aliment of a youth which seems to live 
once more in a revival of its truest aspirations.** 
(New York, George H. Richmond & Co. $9.00.) 

Thanksgivings (tfler the IMy Communion of the 
Body and Blood of Christ. Compiled from 
ancient and modern sources by a layman of 
the American Chnrch. 

Dr. G. McClellan Fiske, in his introduction to 
this volnme, rightly calls the collection "un- 
usual, if not unique.'* Garnered from every field 
of the Church, tnese devotions form a fragrant 
chaplet of pmise. We are glad to see such 

ftrominence given to the thanksgivings from the 
iturgics of the venerable East. That this col- 
lection should have been undertaken, as we 
gather from Dr. Fiske's preface, bv a busy lay- 
man, speaks well for the inner life of such a 
man. Such laymen are the comfort of their 
priests and the joy of the Church. Long may 
we have them. The book is beautifully printed 
and will, we are sure, the more it is known, be 
the better appreciated. (New York, James 
Pott A Co. $1.00.) 

Authors and PuNishers. A Manual of Sugges- 
tions for Beginners in Literature. Seventh 
edition. 

An exquisite sample of the pnblisher*s art. 
Many an author will sigh as he contrasts the 
beauty and elegance lavished on this book of 
su^rgestions with tha uncomely dress in which 
his children have been presented to the public. 
The work is an able plea in behalf of the pub- 
lisher, though it contains very many excellent 
sngeestions for the guidance of amateur authors. 
(Kew York, J. P. Putnam's Sons. $1.75.) 

Books and their Makers during the Middle 
Ages¬ª By George Haven Putnam. Vol. II. 
This second volnme deals with the ]>eriod be- 
tween 1500 and 1709. The first part treats of 
the Estiennes, Casanbon, Caxton, tne Kobergers, 



292 BRIEF KOTES OK CHURCH LITERATURE OF THE YEAR. [1898. 



Froben, Erasmns, Plantin, and the Elcevire. In 
the second part we have a most extensire trea- 
tise on the Dc^nnings of property in literature, 
the priviieffeaand rccnlations In Italy, Germany, 
France, and Englanabeing dealt with separately. 
All lovers of lK>ok8 owe the author a debt of

work now brought to a haopv conclusion, and to 
the eminent firm of whicn be is a member an 
almost eqnal debt for the beautiful dress in 
which the book copies before the public. (New

T?u ScJuolar and the Stale, and Other OratUme 
and Addrestet. By Hknry Codman Potter, 
D.D., Bishop of New York. 
Thoughtrnl readers of these addresses will, 
we think, be struck by the great underlying 
strength of them. The Bishop does not press 
all his arguments to aconclnsion. One feelsthat 
there is a great reserve of force behind them. By 
virtue of nis office a bishop is a ruler, and if he 
is to be a wise ruler be must be a scholar, and if 
his rule Is to be accepted by many conditions of 
men, he must be a statesman. To a lesser 
d^ree, because the sphere of influence is more 
circumscribed, this must be equally true of 
every clergy man, and the doing or our duty to the 
State must surely be comprehended in the doing 
of our duty to our neighbor. Becaui^e the 
noisy partisan or shallow speaker has been to 
the fore in our politics, that is no rea¬´>on why 
the Christian gentleman or priest should retire 
or leave the control of the 8t¬ªte to such men. 
Rather it OQght to be an incentive to them to be 
witnesses of better things. The problems 
touched upon by the Bishop of New York are 
many of them those which affect the very main- 
spring of onr social existence‚Äî the relations of 
science to modem life, Christianity and the crim- 
inal, the rural reinforcement of cities, nobility 
in business, the ministry of music, the gospel for 
wealth. They are dealt with with a calm delib- 
eration, the evident result of long and carefnl 
thinking. (New York, The Century Co. $2.00.) 

Otvek Art on Greek Soil. By James M. Hoppin. 
The title fully describes the work. It is a 
volume dealing with Greek art as seen on Greek 
soil. We thus have a series of fresh and vivid 
impressions of a theme that, old as it is. must 
ever be welcome to all lovers of th6 beautiful in 
art. The buildings, the statues, the very frag- 
ments are thus described in their own setting. 
(New York, Charies 8cribner*s Sons. $2.00.) 

The God Idea qf the Ancients ; or. Sex in Reli- 
gion. By Eliza Bubt Gajtblb. 
The authoress states that the object of the 
book ** is not only to furnish a brier outline of 
religions growth, but to show the effect which 
each of the two forces‚Äî male and female‚Äî has 
had on the development of onr present God- 
idea,'^ but we should put it more plainly as being 
an attempt to prove that the primitive idea wax 
that God was a woman, and that when the world 
shall have progressed far enough it will revert 
to that pristine faith and worship a goddes?*. 
Through the work there runs the calm a¬´scrtion 
that to all superior intellecta Chrisilanity has 
been proved to be a myth. (New York, G. P. 
Putnam's Sons. $2.25.) 



Men I Have Known. By the Vert Rev. Fred- 
erick W. Farbar, D.D. 
Dean Farrar is never dull, and in these chatty 
papers he introduces us and makes us acquainted 
with a very wide variety of celebrities, not only 
ecclesiastics like Tail, Magec, Trench, Benson. 
Newman, Puscv, and Church, but authors and 
statesmen like Bnlwer-Lytton and Beaconsfleld. 
Macaulay, Carlyle, and Dn Maurier, and among 
his American acquaintances we have Emerson, 
Lowell, Longfellow, Whittier, and Chllds. The 
Dean's remarks are all in good taste. The repro- 
duction of several autograph letters add special 
interest to the book. (New Yorlc, Thomas Y. 
Crowell&Co. $1.75.) 

Ex Libris, Essays of a Collector. By Charles 

Dexter Allen. 

A charming series of essayf* full of interest on 
the use of book-plates. Jllastratlons are given 
of fanciful, qnaint^rtistic, and graceful plates. 
(Boston, Lambon, Wolffc <fc Co. $8.00.) 

The Mastery of Books. By Harrt LrxAK 

KoOPlfAN. 

An exceedingly useful little manual for all 
who are endeavoring, by the use of public libra- 
ries, to broaden their culture. The chapters on 
*' What to Read," '' How to Read," and " Read- 
ing Courses " are especially admirable. The 
classified list of books will be found very useful, 
as, besides giving the standard works in general 
literature, it gives tho*¬ªe in special subjects, such 
OS architecture, music, sculpture, pamting, en- 
graving, photography, decoration, etc, etc. 
(New York, American Book Co. 90 cents.) 

T?u Choir Invisible. By James Laxe Allen. 
Wc depart from our custom as to mention of 
novels in these ** Brief Notes " in this instance 
on account of the very peculiar merits of '* The 
Choir Invisible." The story is told with so 
much beauty and strength, the characters are 
so living and real, and the ending so human, 
and therefore so artistic, and the style so charm- 
ing that this work is placed far above the ordi- 
nary level of clever novels. It Is a work of 
genius, reminding us of Hawthorne and Irving. 
(New York, The Macmillan Co. $1.60.) 

Style. By Walter Raleioh. 

A charming and instructive essay. (New 
York, Edwarcf Arnold. $1.50.) 

Vesper Bells and Other Verses. By the Ret. 

H. G. Batterson, D.D. 

The poetic faculty is so rare that it ought to bo 
welcomed wherever met. In several of these 
verses Dr. Batterson has shown that he can be a 
sweet singer of Israel. Those entitled ** Plea¬´i- 
ant Words "and '‚Ä¢Aching Hearts "are especially 
beautiful, and we wiith that some of the carols 
and hymns could be set to music ; they would 
speed fly become great favorites. As a Christmas 
or Easter present this dainty volume will be the 
very gift to knit both donor and receiver together 
by ties of gentle memories. The messages of 
hope and beautv, of sorrow endured, and of vic- 
tory won will bind the reader, the author, and the 
giver Into one chaplet of remembrance. (New 
York, James Pott & Co. $2.00.)

Androniike^ the Heroine of the Greek Revolution. 
By Stephanos Thbodoros I^bnos. Trans- 
lated from the original Greek by Edwin A 
Grosvbnor. 

The plot of this story is not laid In the last 
war, but in that of the revolution of 1821. It is 
full of incident and adventure, and gives in 
vivid color a graphic portrayal of the people, 
their manners and customs. As a novel of 
romance and adventure it ranks very high, 
while its historic setting adds value to its in- 
terest. (Boston, Roberts Brothers. $1.60.)

294 Digitized by GoOglC 



POSTAL BATES. 

{Revised from Official Documenta.) 
Domestic. 

First Class. 2 cents per oz. or fraction thereof. 

Letters within the United States (or for Canada or Mexico). All packages are subject to 
this rate, if sealed, or if ^hey contain any matter of the nature of personal correspondence, ur any 
writing not specially sanctioned nnder Class Three. No limit of size for letters. 

The following are subject to letter rales -.‚ÄîTypewriter matter, stenographic notes, copylng- 

Jiress copies, diaries with entries, and all mauascript, if unaccompanied with printer's proofs 
or the same. 

Postal Cards within the above area, slnele, 1 cent each : reply, 2 cents. Nothing may be 
attached to a postal card except tbac a printed address slip may be pasted on cither side. 
Special Dbliybrt, 10 cents in addition to postage. 

Second Class. General Public Hate. 1 cent per 4 oz. or fraction thereof. 
Full prepayment compulsory. 
Newspapers and Magazines, wrapped to admit inspection. 

These may contain or bear the sender's name and address. They may be marked with pencil 
or Ink to notify any portion ; typographical errors in them may be corrected, and they may bear 
a request to " return if undelivered,^ or the words *' marked copy.'* No limit of weight. Special 
delivery, same as first class. 

Third Class. 1 cent per 2 oz. or fraction thereof. Full prepayment compulsory. 
Not sealed :‚Äî Books, circulars, pamphlets, engravings, lithographs, photographs ; hecto- 
graph, papyrograph, or other such reproductions ; manuscript. If accompaniea with printer's 
proofs Tor the same, and printed matter generally. Seeds, phmts, roots, bulbs, cuttings, and 
scions are, by special regulation, nuulable at third class rates. 

Books may contain a "dedication" or "inscription,** or maybe inscribed outside with a 

request to " return if undelivered," '' from ," or a note of the contents. Christmas and 

other greeting cards may bear a written inscription as '* with good wishes," or the names of 
sender and addressee. Limit of weight, 4 pounds, except for MngTo books. 

Fourth Class. 1 cent per oz. or fraction thereof. FulTprepayment compulsory. 
Merchandise of every kind, such as are not Included In nrst and third classes, patterns, 
samples (which may be Identified with numbers), sample cards, stationery (with or without printed 
headings or addresses), dry goods, confectionery, blauk cards, blank books, diaries, stuffed ani- 
mals, cut flowers, plans, drawings, and designs. Sender's name, contents, or request to " i^tum 
if undelivered " may be inscribed outside. Limit of weight, 4 pounds, except liquids and oils, for 
which limit is four (liquid) ounces. Special delivery, same as first class. 
Domestic Monet Order Fees. 



Not exceeding |2.50, Scents. 



U\ ' 



10 



Not exceeding. 




Not exceeding $75, S6 cents. 
$100, 80 '‚Ä¢ 



Foreign. 



Rates wition the UNnrERSAX Postal Union :‚Äî Letters, 6 cents per \ oz. or fraction 
thereof. Post cards, single, 2 cents ; reply, 4 cents. The largest size of U. 8. postal cards are 
charged as letters in all foreign countries except Canada and Mexico. Printed matter of all kinds, 
1 cent per 2 oz. or fraction thereof. Commercial papers same as printed matter, but lowest 
charge 5 cents. Samples of merchandise same as printed matter, but lowest charge 2 cents. 

The Postal Union Includes Austria, Belgium, British India, Bulgaria, Denmark, England, 
Bgypt, France, Germany, Greece, Hawaii,* Ireland, Italv, Japan, Netherlands, New South Wales, 
Norway, Persia, Porto^, Queensland, Roumania, Russia, Scotland, Servla, Slam, Spain, Sweden, 
Switzerland, Turkey, Victoria, Wales, and mos^t countries In South America. 

China. :‚Äî Postal matter may be sent to Shanghai and 20 other places In China through the 
United States Postal Agency at Shanghai, at Postal Union rates, subject to local delivery cnaiges 
elsewhere than at Shanghai. 

Parcels Post :‚Äî Parcels not exceeding 11 pounds weight, subject to regulations as to size, 
may be sent, at 12 cents per pound and fraction thereof, to Bahamas, Barbados, British Guiana, 
British Honduras, Colomoia, Costa Rica, Danish West Indies, Hawaiian Republic, Jamaica, Lee- 
ward Islands. Mexico, Newfoundland, Salvador, and Windward Islands. 

Note :‚Äî The rates to Canada and Mexico are the same as the United States domestic rates ; 
except that merchandise for Mexico must go by ** Parcels Post¬ª*' and commercial papers and sam- 
ples for Mexico at Postal Union rates. 

For other foreign rates, apply at Post-Ofilce. 

REGISTRATION. 

Domestic and foreign letters and packages are registered for tiie nniform fee of 8 cents, addi- 
tional to the postage ; tney must bear the sender's name and address. 

For foreign matter, the sender, If he desires the return of the receipt card, must so request 
on his letter. 

* When Hawaii becomes part of the United States, domestic postage rates will be applicable.

Tnam ; from 1742 to 1752 to Clonfert; 19 Bps. from 1250 to 1660. See of Clonfert 
founded 5.58; S. Brendan, let Bp.; united to Killaloe in 18^ ; 66 Bps. to 1884. See 
of Kilmacdnogh founded 620 : Colmau MacDuagh. Ist Bp.; 22 Bps. from 1178 to 1587 ; 
then united to Clonfert.) Rt. Rev. Mervtn Archdall, J)A). 1887. Residence, 
Clarisford Uouse, Killaloe. 

Limerick) Ardfert. and Agdahoe.‚Äî (See of Limerick founded about 600 ; S. Munchin, 
Isit Bp.; 50 Bps. from 1106 to 1826. See of Ardfert founded about 500 ; 85 Bps. from 
1075 to 1668 ; then annexed to Limerick.) Rt. Rev. Charles Graves, D.D. 1806. 
Residence, The Palace, Henry Street, Limerick. 



Notes.‚Äî The Diocese of Clonmacnois or Clone was founded In 1548 ; S. Kiafan, 1st Bp.; 69 
Bps. to 1568 ; then arnexed to Meath. The Diocese of Roscrea was founded in 610; S. Cronan, 
1st Bp. ; annexed to Killaloe in 12th century. There are also several minor Sees in County Mayo 
and elsewhere.

THE SUCCESSION OF BISHOPS IN THE 
AMERICAN CHURCH. 

The American Bishops derive their snccession tbrongh the first four Bishops, Seabnrj, White, 
Provoost, and Madiron, and these in torn derived their ftuccession from the Scottish and English 
Episcopate. Bishop Seabary was consecrated by Bishop Kilgoor, Bishop of Al>erdeen and Primas, 
by Bishop Petrie, Bishop of Ross and Moray, and by Binhop SIrinner, Coadjutor to Bishop of 
Aberdeen. Bishop White and Bishop JProvoost were both consecrated on the same day by Arch- 
biiihnp Moore, 88tb Archbishop of Canterbury, by Archbishop Marlcham of York, by Bishop Moss 
of Bath and Wells, and br Bishop Hinchcliile of Peterborongh. Bishop Madison was consecmted 
on September 19, 1790, by Archbishop Moore, by Bishop Portens or London, and by Bishop 
Thomas of Rochester. 

The Scottish Bishops derive their sncceesion through Bishops Sharpe, Fairfoul, Leighton, and 
HamiltOD, who were consecrated on December 15, 1661, by the then Bishops of London, Worcester, 
(.Carlisle, and Llandafl. 

The English Bishops derive their succession from the Apostles 8. John, S. Peter, and S. Paul, 
who in turn derived their succession from our Lord Jesus Christ. 

**XMptf TovTWK (EiruTKOTov, 1rpc<r^vr<pwv, Siaicov¬ª¬•) ckkAi^ia ov KoAeirai. Without these 
(Bishop, Presbyters, Deacons), a Church is not called."‚Äî /|7/ia^4i¬´ EpisUe to the Trailiaru, 1 Hi. 

S. Ignatius was Bishop of Antioch, and a reputed pupil of S. John ; he was martyred under 
Trajan in either a. d. 107 or 116.

It is not to be understood that the functions of the offices indicated by initials pertain In all 
cases to the places given as the post-office address. 

The following initials are given in brackets wherever the canonical residence differs in 
expression from the State in which the postal address is ; where no certain information could be 
procured the bracket has been left blank.

Adtknt, 1896, TO Advbnt, 1897. 



4* Blessed are the dead who die In the Lord. 



John Brockekbrouoh Nbwton, D.D., Bishop Coadjutor of Viroinia. 

Born in Westmoreland Co., Va., Peb. 7, laSfl. EdncHted at Episcopal Hish School of Virginia. 
Qradnated as M.D. from Medical College of Virgrlnia, 1861. Practised medicine for some years. 
Deacon, Juno 85. 1871 ; Priest, Jnne 28, 1878. KectorSoath Pamlium Parish, Essex Co., Va., 
1871-1876 ; S. Luke's, Norfolk, Va., 1876-1891 ; Monumental Church, Richmond, Va.. 1884-1894. 
Consecrated Bishop Coadjutor of Virginia, May, 16, 1894. Died May 88, 1897, in his 59tb year. 

Nelson Sombbvillb Rulison, D.D., Bishop of Central Pennsylvania. 

Bom at Carthage, N. T., April 24, laiS. Graduated from General Theological Seminary, 1866. 
Deacon, May 27, 1866 ; Priest, Nov. SO, 1866. Sometime Curate of Church of the Annunciation, 
New York. Rector, Zlon Church, Morris, N. Y., 1867-1869; S. John's, Jersey City, N. J., 1869- 
1877 ; 8. Panrs, Cleveland, O., 1877-1884. Consecrated Bishop Coadjutor of Central Pennsylvania, 
Oct. 28, 1884. Bishop, July 81 , 1885. Died at Bad Nauheim, Germany, Sept. 1, 1897. 

WiLLUM Adams, D.D. 

Priest of the Diocese of Milwaukee. Bom in 
Monaghan, Ulster, Ireland, July 8, 1813. Grad- 
uated B.A. from Trinltv College, Duhlin, 1H88. 
One of the founders of Nashotah. Deacon, July 



1841 ; started for the far West, Sept., 1841: 
Priest, Oct. 9, 1842. For many years Professor 
of Systematic Divinity in Nashotah Theol(^icjil 
Seminary ; also in charge of churches at Dela- 
field and Pine I.ake. 1878-1886. Died Jan. 2, 
1887, aged 88.

Emeritus S. John's, Oakland, Cal. Rector, S. 
John's. Milwaukee, 1845-1867; S. John'**. Oak- 
land, 1857- lii82. Died Aug. 24, 1897, aged 84.

MONTOOMKRY K. HOOPXR. 

Priest of the Diocese of Central PcnoHylvania.

STEAM ENGINES, PUMPS, TANKS,

And all Appliances for Steam Engineering Supplied. 



Specimens of our apparatus may be seen in hundreds of large buildings in all 
parts of the country, including the Astoria Hotel, at 34th Street and Fifth Avenue ; 
the Plaza and Netherlands Hotels, 59th Street and Central Park ; The Nor- 
mandie ; Metropole ; Union Square ; Broadway Theatre (fan blower system) ; 
New York Life Insurance Co. Buildings at St. Paul, Minn., and Kansas City, 
Mo.; Roman Catholic Cathedral, New York; Public School House, Galveston, 
Texas ; St. Joseph's Hospital, Mott Haven (pure warm air system); Potter Build- 
ing, New York ; HomcEopathic College, 64th Street, - New York (hot water 
circulation); Presbyterian Hospital, 71st Street and Madison Avenue (fan blower 
system), one of the largest jobs for this system in the United States. i

PUBLISHERS. 



The Churchman 



as it enters the fifty-fourth year of its useful career, 
promises its readers and churchmen generally, that during 
1898 it will be more valuable and interesting than ever 
before. Its staff of editors has been largely increased, and 
every department of the paper has been strengthened and 
rendered more effective. 

Aside from purely religious subjects to which The 
Churchman will primarily devote its attention, plans have 
been perfected in order that what is best in the domain of 
Art, Literature, and Music will be discussed by specialists 
in an entertaining and instructive manner. 

THE GENERAL CONVENTION‚Äî Great interest 
attaches to the coming General Convention, to meet in 
1898 at Washington. The discussions of important sub- 
jects to be considered there, and the report of the proceed- 
ings, are alone worth more than a year's subscription. 

There are many interesting features of The Churchman 
which render it invaluable to every churchman, but there 
is not space to enumerate them. Please send for pros- 
pectus, with sample copy of The Churchman, which will 
be sent promptly on application. 

Subscription price, to the laity, $3.50 a year; to the 
clergy, $3.00 a year ; trial subscription, six weeks, twenty- 
five cents. 



THE CHURCHMAN COMPANY, 

47 Lafayette Place, New York Cffy. i

NELSON'S NEW SERIES OF 
TEACHERS' BIBLES. 



New Illustrations, 
New Helps.

New Maps. 



These Teachers' Bibles Contain New Bible Helps, entitled **The 

Illustrated Bible Treasury," written by Leading 

Scholars in America and Great Britain. 

UPWARDS OF 350 ILLUSTRATIONS 

OF ANCIENT MONUMENTS, SCENES IN BIBLE LANDS, ANIMALS, PLANTS, ANTIQUITIES, 
COINS, ETC, ARE DISTRIBUTED THROUGH THE TEXT OF THE HELPS. 



*' To the contents of * The Treasury * 
the very first scholars of England and 
America have contributed. Thirty- eight 
men, the specialists of Biblical learning, 
have been employed in this work. The 
Teachers' Bible puts into a brief compass 
all the learning of Biblical interpreters, 
and places its results in the hands of the 



people. We pronounce this edition of the 
Bible not only a magnificent tribute to 
the worth and permanence of the great 
Book as a piece of inspired literature, but 
also a convenient, most concise, complete 
and beautiful storehouse^of Scriptural 
knowledge and study."

ST. MATTHEW, ST. MARK, and the GENERAL EPISTLES. Ready in January . The 
title indicates the contents of this volume. It will also include Tlu Epistus to tk* Hebrews, 
thus giving the complete New Testament in the four volumes. 

ST. LUKE and ST. PAUL. Ready in April. A Double Number‚Äî Two Volumes. J ho Gospel 
o/St. Luke will be followed by The Acts of the Apostles, with the Pauline Epistles introduced 
at the several points of the history to which the^ are usually referred. It gives an opportunity 
of studying the unbroken History of the New Testament Church. 

ST. JOHN. Ready in May, This volume will contain the Gospel, Epistles, and Revelation of 
St. John. 

tk.r\r\f\\\r\nf^rr\f^r\f The Macmillan Company calls attention to a change of plans by 
millUUllCCillClll. ^hich that volume of the Modern Reader's Bible, containing St, 
Matthew, St. Mark, and the General Epistles appear early in January instead of as at first an- 
nounced,iny4/r/V. Thus those who are expecting to use the first Gospel in Sunday School work during 
that month can count upon having the aid of this convenient form of the text. No daintier gift, by 
the way, could be made to a member of one's class than one of these little leather bound volumes.

-The Watchman, 



The Life of Philip Schaff. 

By David S. Schaff, Professor of Church History in Lane Theological Seminary. With 

portraits. Svo, $3.00. 

The life of the late Dr. Schaff was a particularly representative one. Bom a Swiss and 
educated in Germany, he passed his mature life in America, connected closely with the theo- 
logical instruction of youth, with the liberal movement in Biblical criticism, and with the 
Evangelical Alliance. He was a scholar of world-wide reputation and left much material of 
especially varied interest, on which his son has based an instructive biography. 

The Place of Death in Evolution. 

By Newman Smyth, D.D., New Haven, Conn, xamo, $1.25. 

"His reasoning is dose, calm and lucid, his intellectual grasp masterly, while his st)Ie is aim- 
plidtv itself."‚Äî C*r 1/ an Advocate. 

" An ideal example of the best 
themes.*'‚Äî TA^ Independent.

PUBLISHERS. 



JUST PUBLISHED: 

HYMNAL OF THE CHURCH, 
WITH MUSIC. 

Edited by Rev. James H. Darlington, D.D., Rector of Christ 
Church, Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y. 

THE NEED. 

The great need of an edition of the Revised Hymnal, 
with music in compact form for the use of choir and 
congregation alike, has been widely felt throughout the 
Church. To supply the demand for a book that is satis- 
factory from a musical standpoint, yet portable in form, 
is the object of the present edition. The editor, in his 
own parish, felt the want of a musical Hymnal that could 
be placed in every pew at a moderate cost; one that would 
grive to the congregation, in a single, handy volume, the 
very best popular Church music. His need has been that 
of nearly every parish priest in the land, and, to meet it, 
a book answering such requirements has been most care- 
fully prepared. Hearty, soul-stirring congregational 
singing can now be had in our churches with this new 
edition of the Hymnal in the hands of the worshippers. 
Rectors and Organists are invited to give it a careful 
examination. 

DESCRIPTION. 

Size, i2mo (4^^ x 7 inches); weight, 14 ounces; printed on pure white 
** Bible" paper, of durable texture and great opaqueness; binding simple, attractive, 
and dignified. 

STYLES OF BINDING. 

Style I, Cloth (black, dark purple, maroon, or red), with red edges, bound so as to 

open freely. 75 cents net; by mail, 85 cents. 
Style 2, French Seal Leather, square corners, gplt edges. $1.50 net; by mail, $r.6o. 
Style 3, Turkey Morocco, limp, round corners, gilt edges. $2.50 net ; by mail, $2.60. 

ly These prices are strictly net. All orders for ten or more will be forwarded 

charges prepaid. 

Descriptive Circular and Commendations sent free on application. 




THOMAS V^HITTAKER, Publisher, 

2 and 3 Bible House, New York.

PUBLISHERS. 



ly The Uniform Sunday School Lessons of the Diocesan Committees are now 
used by more than j^o^(x>o pupi/s, 

ANNOUNCEMENT. 

The Sunday School Lessons 

FOR 1898. 



Clergymen or Sunday School Workers are invited to examine the Quarterly 
Publications edited by the Rev. George W, Shinn, D.D. These Lessons have 
for twenty years followed the uniform scheme of the Joint Diocesan Committees, 
whose lessons are now studied regularly by over three hundred and fifty thousand 
children in our Sunday Schools, and have the hearty endorsement of nearly every 
Bishop and Rector in the land. The theme of lessons from Advent, 1897, to 
Trinity, 1898, is on "The Life of our Lord." // is one of the most interestin/^ 
series of lessons in the Committee s schedule. The four publications edited by 
Dr. Shinn Ofc as follows : 

PICTURE LESSONS 

(for Primary and Junior Grades), 12 cents per year. 

THE LESSON BOOK 

(for Middle and Senior Grades), 12 cents per year. 

THE BIBLE CLASS MANUAL, 

20 cents per year. 

THE TEACHERS' ASSISTANT, 

25 cents per year. 



These Quarterlies have a larger circulation than ail similar 
publications combined^ and having been issued under the one editor 
and one publisher for many years^ subscribers can depend upon a 
ripe and experienced editorships together with promptness in public 
cation and delivery. 



A SAMPLE OF EACH FOR EXAMINATION WILL BE SENT 
FREE ON APPLICA TION. ADDRESS 

THOMAS WHITTAKER, Church Publisher 
2 AND 3 Bible House, New Yorkw , 

Digitized by LjOOQIC 



PUBLISHERS. 



THE 

General Board of Missions 

Legal Title [for use in making wills]: The Domestic 
and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal 
Church in the United States of America. 

Offerings are asked to sustain missions in nineteen missionary 
jurisdictions and forty-one home dioceses, including missions to 
the Indians and the colored people in our land, as well as missions 
in China, Japan, Africa, Haiti,- and Greece ‚Äî to pay the salaries and 
traveling expenses within their jurisdictions of twenty-one Bishops, 
and stipends to 1,478 missionary workers, and to support schools, 
hospitals, and orphanages. $650,000 are asked for this year ; 
relying upon the generous offerings of men, women and children 
in all parts of the Church. Remittances should be made payable 
to Mr. George C. Thomas, Treasurer, and communications should 
be addressed to the General Secretary, Church Missions House, 
281 Fourth Avenue, New York. 

THE children's LENTEN OFFERING 

has been the means of largely increasing the gfifts of Sunday- 
Schools, for Missions. Every Sunday-School should join in this* 
movement and make the offering at Easter, 1898, reach $100,000, 
as a memorial of the late Rev. Dr. Langford. 

THE YOUNG CHRISTIAN SOLDIER 

is the children's illustrated paper, published weekly and monthly. 
Weekly issue: single copies, 80 cents; packages of 10 or more to one 
address, 54 cents a copy per annum, in advance. Monthly issue: 
single copies, 10 cents; packages of 10 or more to one address, 
5 cents a copy per annum, in advance. Send for specimen copies. 

THE QUARTERLY MESSAGE 

concerning Church Missions at Home and Abroad. For general 
circulation among the laity. 8 pp. ; 5 x 7 in. Copies of single 
issue, $1 per hundred. Subscriptions: single copies, 10 cents 
per annum; packages at the rate of $4 per hundred per annum. 
Send for specimen copy. 

THE SPIRIT OF MISSIONS 

published monthly, at one dollar per year, is the official missionary 
organ of the Church, and should be in every household. Send for 
specimen copy. _ gitj.ed by GoOglc

Contains the full order of Evening Prayer from the Prayer- Book, and four Hymns.

sent on application.

PUBLISHERS. 



The Living Church 

EstablUhed CHICAGO 



A WEEKLY CHURCH JOURNAL AND FAMILY PAPER. 



Rev. C. W. LEFFINGWELL, D.D., 

Editor and Proprietor. 

Subscription^ in advance^ $2,00, To the Clergy , in advance ^ i^^-jo. 



rpHE LIVING CHURCH aims to give a weekly record of 
the Work, the News and the Thought of the Church, with 
especial reference to the Anglican Communion, and the interests 
of that portion of it ** known in law*' as The Protestant Episcopal 
Church in the United States. Reports of diocesan and parish 
work are furnished by paid correspondents in all great Church 
centers; Church questions are frankly and fairly discussed in the 
editorial columns; public opinion is voiced in ** Letters to the 
Editor*'; current literature finds abundant room on "The Editor's 
Table"; entertaining reading is provided for the young. Only 
high-class advertisements are solicited. 

SPECIMEN COPIES FREE, 
LIBERAL COMMISSIONS, 

Address THE LIVING CHURCH, CHICAGO. 

Digitized by LjOOQIC 



PUBLISHERS. 



xxxiii 



The Church Standard 



With the issue of November 6ch, 1897, The 
Church Standard published ihe first number 
of its twelfth volume under the present editorial 
management. It appeared in a new **dress," 
and with an increase in its reading matter, 
which will be maintained throughout the year. 

The Church Standard will continue to be 
true to the Catholic Church, and therefore true 
to the Protestant Episcopal Church. It will 
remain perfectly independent and absolutely 
free from party spirit. It will treat questions 
which may arise from time to time in the 
Church with the utmost candor, njt expecting' 
that its views will always be right, but desiring, 
so far as it can, to assist in the forming of a 
wise and charitable public opinion. 

The Foreign Correspondence, which is uni- 
versally admired, will be enlarged by communi- 
cations from an expert in the ecclesiastical 
movements of Europe. 

The Home News will be increased and in- 
clude letters from special correspondents in all 
the principal citie&of the country. 

The "Open Court" affords an opportunity 
for free expression of opinion by correspondents. 



whether they may agree or disagree with the 
views of the editor. 

The department of Music and Art gives 
week by week a new piece of sacred music, with 
notes on all matters of interest pertaining to 
this department. 

The Book Notices are carefully and conscien- 
tiously written. Reviews of theological and 
technical works are furnished by experts. 

The Home Reading will be greatly enlarged. 
It will contain " The Parson's Outlook," by 
the well-known W. B. B.; a Short Sermon on 
the Christian Life, by an American bishop or 
presbyter; original articles on topics of contem- 
porary interest; selections from other period- 
icals; a column of Notes for Men and another 
column of Notes for Women. 

The Children's Comer is in competent 
hands. Its purpose is to instruct as well as 
to interest and amuse our juvenile readers. 
The Puzzle Department of the Children's 
Comer, we are glad to say, is not only appre- 
ciated by our young readers, but has received 
very high commendation from a distinguished 
professor of mathematics.

Among the contributors are many of the ablest writers in the Protestant 
Episcopal Church in the United States. Articles on current and vital topics of 
interest to the Church appear every month.

ST. ANDREW'S CROSS 

THE INTERNATIONAL ORGAN OF THE BROTHERHOOD OF 

ST. ANDREW. 

Numbers among its subscribers thousands of men and women who are not members of the 
Brotherhood, but who value ST. ANDREW'S CROSS because it is newsy, practical and pro- 
gressive, in addition to recording the work of the Brotherhood, it gives information concerning 
all important happenings in the Church. Its low subscription price places it within reach of alL 

The special International Convention number is now ready and contains among other 
notable features: 

THE DIVINE WITNESS. ) ^ r .^^^ r-^o.^ 

INDIVIDUAL AND CORPORATE WORK, f ^X ^anon oore.

Of Rochester

WHAT ARE THE CONDITIONS OF TRUE SOCIAL PROGRESS? Bv 

Jacob A. Riis. 
THE BIBLE AND HUMAN FREEDOM. By Bishop Doane. 
THE LNSTITUTION. By Bishop Gailor. 
EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYEES. By W. R. Stirling, Canon Gore, and 

the Bishop ok Rochester. 

And many other addresses by Bishops, Clergymen and Laymen.

A LOYAL CHURCH PAPER FOR THE PEOPLE. 

Church Bells 

AN ILLUSTRATED MAGAZINE OF THE EPISCOPAL 
CHURCH. ADAPTED TO LOCALIZATION. 

Subscription : jo cents a year. Single copies : j cents each, 

JO copies y per year^ $2.00. 100 copies^ per months $2.00. 

( Tiventy-five cents per hundred extra ^ where mailed to individuals.) 

pHURCH BELLS, in the past years /CHURCHMEN 
^^ of its existence, has exerted a I should read and 

marked influence upon the people of the V^>4lRCULATE IT, 

parishes in which it has circulated. It 

has aroused the careless, informed the ignorant, raised the standard 
of sound Churchmanship, and converted a number of those outside 
the Church to her doctrines and usages. 

PARISH SUPPLEMENT consists of the 8 inside pages of 
Church Bells (for parochial distribution). $1.50 per hundred. 

HAVE A PARISH PAPER 

nrHE "CHURCH BELLS" arrangement provides an interesting, attractive 
‚Ä¢‚ñ†‚ñ† paper at far less cost than a wholly local paper. Rectors can depend upon it 
to contain only sound Church teaching. 

MO\A7 ? ^^ y^" ^^^ "^* situated near New York it is best to have your local 
11 \J VV ‚Ä¢ printing done at home, and let us furnish you with blanks. 
"RT A ISTK'Q Sp^^S^^y are furnished with small head that is cut off in the trim, 
‚ñ†L5i-'r\iN JVo carriage free for $1.50 per hundred. (Style A.) 

This necessitates a 4 page local paper. 

12 pages y with I or 2 pages left blank, for $2.00 per hundred. 

4pa^es, with i page blank, for $1.00 per hundred. 

4 pages ^ with 2 pages blank, for 75 cents per hundred. 
T f\(^ A T TC CT TPrC printed entire by us, cost $5.00 for the first hundred, 
'*-'vJV^/\J-* 100 U lio including i page of locals. Each additional hundred 

costs $2.00, and each additional local page costs ^2.50; thus 300 copies, 2 pages 

local, would be $11.50 per month, ft can be used ten months in the year or 

quarterly. Covers with desirable advertising supplied free. 

A T'i'l/pr'RXT^PTVjf PTKrXQ properly handled, can be made to pay the 
r\LJ V JJ^JX 1 loXiiVliiiM 1 O, cost of the paper, and give a parish a 
valuable medium (that could not otherwise be afforded). The best \yay to o 
handle the advertising is to divide the last page into 27 blocks of i inch, charge 
$2.00 each for a year, which means an income of $54.00. By having the adver- 
tisements set once, and then electrotyped, the cost of the advertising page 
would be but 85 cents per issue, making the paper cost the parish but $4. 50 
per year. A subscription price ought always to be charged and nearly all this 
revenue can be applied to parochial objects.

PUBLISHERS. 



THE NEW EDUCATION SERIES OF 

Primary Lessons 

FOR CHURCH SUNDAY-SCHOOLS. 



BY 



MISS MARY E. HUTCHESON 



These Lessons, designed to provide 
four years of graded instruction for 
children in the Primary Department, are 
thoroughly in accord with modern edu- 
cational thought, as to the best methods 
of teaching the young, as well as 
Churchly in character. The author, a 
Churchwoman, is a trained teacher of 
wide experience in both secular and 
religious educational work. The First 
and Second Year's Lessons (now ready) 
include : 

"The Old, Old Story of Jesus 
AND His Love," 

a series of Lessons for the first half of 
the Church Year, each Lesson being as 
far as possible in harmony with the 
Gospel for the Day, and 

**The Disciples of Jesus; or, 

Stories of the Apostles, 

Saints and Martyrs," 

a series of Lessons for the Trinity 
Season. 

In the presentation of the above a 
Picture Lesson Leaf with simple home 
work is provided for the youngest chil- 
dren, or children of kindergarten age, and 
a Primary Lesson Leaflet (four pages) 
with Sewing Card for children of the 
First Primary Grade ; and the same 
Primary Lesson Leaflet with a Text 
Card (to be colored by the children) for 
the Additional or Substitute Year. 

In providing home work for the 
youngest children, the Picture Lesson 



Leaf aims to impress upon them only a 
few of the most important points in 
each lesson. It is designed that each 
child shall spend at least two years upon 
the same lesson material. 

The Lesson Subjects for the First, 
Second and Third Years are as follows: 

I.‚Äî "THE OLD, OLD STORY." 

First Sunday in Advent. The Story begun. 
Second Sundajr in Advent. The Promise. 
Third Sunday in Advent. The Messenger. 
Fourth Sunday in Advent. The Babe of Beth- 
lehem. (Two Picture Cards.) 
First Sunday after Chrbtmas. The Babe 

Named and Taken to the Temple. 
Second Sunday after Christmas. The Visit of 

the Wise Men. 
First Sunday after the Epiphany. The Boy 

Jesus in the Temple. 
Second Sunday after the Epiphany. The 

Water Made Wine. 
Third Sunday after the Epiphany. The 

Soldier*s Servant. 
Fourth Sunday after the Epiphany. A Storhi 

at Sea. 
Septuagesima. Laborers in the Vineyard. 
Sexagesima. The Parable of the Sower. 
Quinquagesima. Light to the Blind. 
First Sunday in Lent. Jesus in the Wilderness. 
Second Sunday in Lent. Jesus Enters Jerusalem. 
Third Sunday in Lent. The Last Sapper. 
Fourth Sundajr in Lent. Jesus in the Garden. 
Fifth Sunday in Lent. Jesus in the Judgment 

Sunday Next Before Easter. Jesus on the 

Cross, n'wo Picture Cards.) 
Easter day. Jesus Risen. 
First Sunday after Easter. The Walk to 

Emmans. 
Second Sunday after Eastern Peace be Unto 

You. 
Third Sunday after Easter. Feed Bily Lambs. 
Fourth Sunday after Easter. The Promise of 

the Comforter. 
Fifth Sunday after Easter. The Ascenston. 
Sunday after the Ascension. Waiting for the 



PUBLISHERS. 



Promise of the Father. 
Whitsunday. The Gift of the Holy Ghost. 
Trinity Sunday. The Holy Trinity. 

II. ‚Äî The Disciples of Jesus; or, 

Stories of the Apostles, Saints 

AND Martyrs. 

The Lessons are on S. Andrew. S. Thomas, 
S. Stephen, S. John (Evangelist), The Conver- 
sion of S. Paul. S. Matthias, S. Mark, S. Philip 
and S. James, S. Bartholomew, S. Matthew, S. 
Luke, S. Simon and S, Jude, S. Ignatius, S. 
Alban, S. Patrick, S. Columba, S. Augustine 
and S. Aidan, S. Boniface, All Saints. 

With the use of the (i) "Picture Lesson 
Leaf," (2) " The Primary Lesson with Sewing 
Cards," and (3) " The Primary Lessons with 
Text Cards," the above constitute a course of 
three years* instruction. While the main topic 
is the same throughout, the mode of studying 
and doing the lesson is varied to such an extent 
as to make, practically, three distinct lesson<:, 
devoid of repetition or monotony. 

THREE GRADES 
are provided for by the lessons now ready. 

TEACHERS' MANUAL. 
A Teachers' Manual in four parts containing 
all necessary helps for teachers, as well as other 



matter of general interest to Primarj' Sunday 
School workers, is also provided. 

THE NEXT GRADE. 

In Advent, 1898, it is purposed to follow the 
first series of lessons with 

*' The Promised Messiah; or. Stories of Those 
who Waited for the Saviour," a series of lessons 
on Old Testament Characters, with lesson leaf- 
let and home work adapted to children of the 
Second Primary Grade. 

The Publication of the Concluding Series for 
the Third Primary Grade will follow. 

THE NEW EDUCATION. 

Tn the preparation of the New Education 
Series (^Primary Lessons the aim has been not 
only to have the subject matter and its method 
of presentation adapted to the child^ but to 
make these first lessons fundamental as to 
their relation to the whole story of Christian 
truth which the Church teaches a child must 
'^ Know and Believe to his soul's health." 

Use is made in these lessons of the Church's 
svrabolism in color and design in recognition of 
the educational principle '' that the child in his 
progress toward the spiritual and the invisible 
*nay be led by the concrete and the msibley 

These lessons are the first of their kind to he 
printed in colors to emphasize the teaching of 
the Church's seasons. 



PRICES : 

**The Old, Old Story," and **The Disciples of Jesus." (One Year.) 

I‚ÄîFOR THE YOUNGEST SCHOLARS. (Kindergarten age.) Picture 
Lesson Leaf. Single copies, 25 cents a year; 10 cents a quarter. Ten or 
more copies to one address, 15 cents a year for each copy; 5 cents a quarter. 

11‚Äî FIRST PRIMARY GRADE. Primary Lesson Leaflet with Sewing Card. 
Single copies, 50 cents a year; 15 cents a quarter. Ten or more copies to one 
address, 30 cents a year for each copy; 10 cents a quarter. 

Ill‚Äî ADDITIONAL OR SUBSTITUTE YEAR. Primary Lesson Leaflet 
with Text Card. The prices are the same as with Sewing Card. 

IV‚Äî TEACHERS' MANUAL. Published quarterly. Single copies, 15 cents, 
postpaid. Yearly subscription, 50 cents. 

ALL ORDERS ARE PAYABLE STRICTLY IN ADVANCE.

HOSPITAL. 




THE INEBRIATES' HOME 

FORT HAMILTON, N. Y 

INCORPORATED 1866. 

A Hospital for the Treatment of 

Alcoholism and the Opium Habit. 



President‚Äî JOHN NEVILLE. 
Vice-Pres.‚Äî M. J. KENNEDY. Treas.‚Äî Hon. JOHN COWENHOVEN. 
Sec. and Supt.‚Äî SAMUEL A. AVILA. Auditor‚Äî FRANKLIN COLEMAN. 



We are enabled to offer Board, Washing and Medical Attendance at rates varying from $to 10 
$35 per week. Patients are received either on their application, or by due process of law. For 
mode and terms of admission apply to the Superintendent at the ** Home,'* 89th Street and Second 
Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y., or at the Office, No. 9 Court Square, Brooklyn, N. Y. 



HOW TO REACH THE INSTITUTION FROM NEW YORK. 

Cross the East River to Brooklyn on Fulton Ferry boat or Bridge, and proceed by Third 
Avenue electric cars to Fort Hamilton ; or cross, from South Ferry on Hamilton Avenue boat or by 
3Qih Street Ferry, to Brooklyn, and proceed by electric cars to Fort Hamilton. Request the con- 
ductor to leave you at 89th Street and 'I'hird Avenue. 



Telephone Connection, 



P, 0. Box 42, Station N, Brooklyn, AT, V.
